texts.en: Yam P., a modest villager living in the province of Banteay Meanchey, Cambodia, is divorced and takes care of three children studying in the local public school. Yam P.’s current income is not enough for her family’s daily expenses, so she hopes to earn additional revenue by using a loan from Kiva’s partner HKL to order gas to sell.

texts.en: Ni Made Sarmi (DNR.M-0576) is a 28-year-old female living in the town of Desa Perancak, Negara. She is married and has an infant child. Ni Made Sarmi owns and operates a business raising pigs for sale. She has been engaged in this business for over six years and earns approximately 200,000 IDR a month. In 2008, Ni Made Sarmi joined DINARI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is now requesting a loan of 4,125,000 IDR which will be used to purchase piglets to raise and sell. The loan will be her first from DINARI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. About DINARI: The mission of DINARI is to strive for the preservation of the environment, to empower the poor, and to provide socio-economic development opportunities to small business owners. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Bahasa while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders. ***************************************************** Ni Made Sarmi - (DNR.M-0576) merupakan 28 tahun wanita. Dia (perempuan) tinggal di kota Desa Perancak - Negara. Dia (perempuan) menikah dan memiliki 1 anak usia balita. Untuk membiayai hidup, Ni Made Sarmi memiliki & menjalankan usaha. Bisnis beroperasi di sektor pertanian. Tujuan utama bisnis tersebut adalah memelihara ternak. Meskipun bukan satu-satunya sarana untuk menghasilkan pendapatan, sumber utama penghasilan bisnis tersebut terutama berasal dari beternak babi untuk dijual. Ni Made Sarmi sudah menjalankan bisnis ini selama lebih dari 6 tahun. Dari kegiatan-kegiatan ini, Ni Made Sarmi menghasilkan sekitar 200,000 IDR sebulan. Dalam 2008, Ni Made Sarmi bergabung DINARI untuk mendapatkan akses ke layanan keuangan untuk membantu meningkatkan -nya kondisi kehidupan dan kemampuan untuk menjalankan kegiatan bisnis. Ni Made Sarmi telah berhasil melunasi pinjaman sebelumnya dari DINARI. Dia (perempuan) sekarang meminta pinjaman baru sebesar 4,125,000 IDR. Pinjaman saat ini akan digunakan untuk untuk membeli bibit ternak untuk dibesarkan & dijual di masa mendatang. Pinjaman ini akan menjadi 2nd pinjaman yang diambil oleh peminjam dari DINARI. Ni Made Sarmi berencana untuk menggunakan pendapatan tambahan yang dihasilkan dari bisnis untuk mendukung keuangan anggota keluarga langsung peminjam. Tentang DINARI: Misi DINARI adalah memperjuangkan kelestarian lingkungan, memberdayakan kaum miskin, dan menyediakan kesempatan pembangunan sosial ekonomi bagi pemilik usaha kecil. *Catatan: Untuk memaksimalkan efisiensi & menurunkan biaya, pinjaman ini ditempelkan menggunakan templat sehingga dapat diterjemahkan otomatis oleh Kiva. loans.name: Chan

texts.en:
The smiling face shown in the photo is Mrs. Chan S., age 25, who lives in Banteay Meanchey Province. She is looking for a loan to buy house repair materials to support her husband’s business activities, working in construction.

Chan S. is a young mother caring for two young kids who are enrolled in the primary school. Presently, she sells different kinds of vegetables in the market to earn a living. She can generate $2 or $3 of income per day to contribute to her family’s food.

loans.use: To buy house repair materials for her husband's business

loans.name: Rosemarie

texts.en:
34-year-old Rosemarie M. has five children with her husband, Alexis Mellero. Her eldest child is a grade five student and her youngest child is five years old.

Rosemarie knew that she had to be hardworking to achieve her dreams of sending all her five children to school until college and to build a stable house someday. She knew that she had to have a business of her own since she has no one to depend on to sustain the needs of her children and to give them a better kind of living - eating regular meals with enough food and better clothing. Her husband, Alexis, understood where his wife's feelings were coming from because he is in prison.

Rosemarie, came from a very poor family. She wanted to have her own business if her children were not to experience the bitter experiences that poverty had given her. When ASHI came one day and knocked on her door, she embraced the opportunity of loaning to achieve her vision of having her own business.

Now, her loanable amount is bigger and she has more options to enhance her business of buying and selling first-aid medicines. For the loan she has applied for now, she will not only be changing her own family life but also the lives of poor families in their village. Her business gives people access to first-aid medicines and provides services such as checking their blood-pressure.

With all of the adversities caused by poverty, Rosemarie's hope is with the loans she can obtain from ASHI.

loans.use: To buy first-aid medicines to sell and a stethoscope

loans.name: I Gede Merta Wijaya

texts.en:
I Gede Merta Wijaya (DNR.M-0579) is a 33-year-old man living in the town of Melaya. He is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, I Gede Merta Wijaya owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs to sell. I Gede Merta Wijaya has been engaged in this business for over 8 years and earns approximately 200,000 IDR a month from these activities.

In 2007, I Gede Merta Wijaya joined DINARI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. I Gede Merta Wijaya is now requesting a new loan of 4,500,000 IDR, which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in the future. The loan will be the 4th loan taken out by the borrower from DINARI. I Gede Merta Wijaya plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support members of his immediate family.

About DINARI:
The mission of DINARI is to strive for the preservation of the environment, to empower the poor, and to provide socio-economic development opportunities to small business owners.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Bahasa while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Omiraw Group

texts.en:
Omiraw is the group leader of the Omiraw group. There are four members in this group. They would like to expand their businesses. They want to make a loan of 40000 Afghani. 

Omiraw wants to make a loan for her husband who has fuel selling shop. Nafesa wants to make a loan for the business of embroidery. Nazaq wants to make a loan for her husband who has taxi driver. Sharefa wants to make a loan for her husband who has general store. 

The group members are happy with this process that allows them to make loans in Afghanistan.

loans.use: To expand their businesses.

loans.name: Kong's Group

texts.en:
There are four low-income people who have decided to seek a loan for different purposes. One of these people, Mrs. Kong S., 46, has been chosen to be the leader of this loan group by the other members. Kong S. currently works cleaning rooms for a small firm. She gets a specific salary of $70 a month to manage her family’s needs. She is married with one teenage child who is still unemployed, while her husband works in construction. Kong S. currently faces difficulties with water system use; she always buys water for her own family's use at an expensive price from her neighbors. She hopes to reduce this cost by using a loan to pay for connecting a new water system. The other three borrowers are: Mr. Uk S., a security guard, who is asking for a loan to pay for connecting a watering system; Mr. Keo S., who will be using the loan money to pay the water system fee; and Mrs. San C., who is requesting a loan to buy a motor for the family’s traveling needs.

Note: Mr. Uk S. and Mr. Keo S. were not available for photographing, so their wives are shown in the picture instead.

loans.use: To pay for connecting a new water system

loans.name: Sanatillo

texts.en:
MLF “MicroInvest” is a leading microfinance organization, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sought to transform into a microloan deposit-taking organization. Therefore, in October of 2008, MLF “MicroInvest,” together with LLC “Frontiers,” founded the limited liability company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand.”

“Arvand,” being the assignee of “MicroInvest,” continues to carry out its mission, which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan.

E. Sanatillo is 39 years old. He lives in the Zafarabad region of Tajikistan. He is married and has 3 children. Sanatillo first applied to "MicroInvest" in 2006 for a business development loan. Thanks to the loan, he was able to buy a car and to start a business as a taxi driver. Sanatillo works as a taxi driver, and it is his general income. He applies to KIVA with the request of a business support loan of 1,000 TJS for 10 months for the purpose of car repairing. He thanks KIVA for its support and wishes all the best.

loans.use: Capital for car repairing

loans.name: Banazer Group
loans.use: For business progress

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en: Rebecca P. is from the village of Sto. Ñino, Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur. She is 64 years old, married, and has five adult children. Rebecca owns and operates a clothing-sales business, primarily selling clothes in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 1,500 PHP a month. In 2008, Rebecca joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. Rebecca is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her second from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

location.town: Sto. Niño, Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur

loans.name: Hamad Group

texts.en:
Hamad is the group leader of Hamad Group. There are three members in this group and they each want to take a loan to progress their business and make it larger. So they are requested a group of loan 42,000 Afghani.

Hamad wants to take a loan for his fruit-selling shop.

Zharmena wants to take a loan for her tailoring business.

Havfeza wants to take a loan for her husband who is a taxi driver.

So they are all happy with this process of loans in Afghanistan that is able to support all poor people.

loans.use: To expand his fruit-selling business

loans.name: Melonida

texts.en:
Melonida M., from the village of Manguehan, Lopez Jaena, Misamis Occidental, is the 40-year-old married mother of six school-aged children. To make a living, Melonida owns and operates a lumber business whose main source of income comes from selling wood and wood-related products. Melonida, engaged in her business for over 20 years, earns approximately 2000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Melonida joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having fully repaid a previous loan of 4000 PHP from GDMPC, she is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be her second from GDMPC, and she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisher folk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business.

loans.name: Hermenia

texts.en:
Hermenia P. is a 50-year-old woman who has three children with her husband, Quirino P.. Her eldest child is in her second year of college taking Hotel and Restaurant Management; the second to eldest is a third-year high school student; and the youngest is in his sixth grade in elementary. Every year, the education of Hermenia's children incurs bigger financial expenses. Hermenia's business had been very helpful in supporting those expenses and has abled her children to continue their studies.

It has been thirty years that Hermenia is into her business buying and selling fish. Her membership in ASHI and the support of her loving husband and children enabled her to start up the business and have it grow. Despite financial struggles, Hermenia proved her trustworthiness and well-defined values by showing good performance in terms of her repayments, attendance and business.

Recently, Hermenia, her husband and her children decided to apply for a loan in ASHI to enhance her business further and it could profit greatly. The whole family agreed on the idea of buying more variety of fish and to increase the volume of their purchases in order to sell more, cover a wider area of the municipality, and have bigger profits. Aside from intending Hermania's loan for her primary business, they also plan to enhance their hog-fattening business (backyard pig-raising to be sold after four months) for an alternative income during the off-season of fish.

Through the profit Hermenia's hog fattening business would generate, she aspires to purchase a motor fishing boat to be managed by her husband while her profit from buying and selling fish will be intended for her weekly repayments to ASHI, family daily needs, and her children's education.

loans.use: To buy a greater variety of fish to sell and to buy feed for her pig-raising

loans.name: Esterlita

texts.en:
Esterlita R., from the village of Calaran, Calamba, Misamis Occidental, is a 44-year-old married mother of four adult-aged children. To make a living, Esterlita owns and operates a sari-sari or general store whose main source of income comes from selling daily-use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, etc. in the local community. Engaged in her business for over five years, she earns approximately 3000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Esterlita joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is now requesting a loan of 5000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Esterlita from GDMPC, and she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Junaidullo

texts.ru: Боев Чунайдулло 1981 года рождения. Женат, имеет 2-х детей. Он занимается продажей бытовыми товарами. Он торгует в Центральном рынке  города Вахдат. Чунайдулло  закупает товар в городе Душанбе из оптового рынка «Корвон». Он ездит за товаром 3 раз в месяц. В этом бизнесе у него 5 лет опыта. Он хочет с помощью Кива получить займ в сумме 10000 сомони, и увеличить свой оборотный капитал.
texts.en:
Junaidullo B. was born in 1981. He is married and has two children and is engaged in the sale of household goods. He trades them in the central market of the city of Vahdat. Junaidullo buys the goods in bulk in the city of Dushanbe from the wholesale market "Korvon". He travels here three times a month for goods, and he has had 5 years of experience in this business. He hopes with the help of Kiva he will obtain a loan in the sum of 10,000 TJS (2,300$), and increase his revenue.

Translated from Russian by Maria Lyuksyutova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of Household Goods

loans.name: Floravie

texts.en:
Floravie C. is 27 years old and a mother of three children, ages five, four, and two years old. Her children are the angels that keep the bond of her marriage to Vincent C., a utility worker in one of the offices in the municipality of San Jose.

After five years of being married, Floravie saw how hard life can be if her husband alone was earning. She wanted to have her own business to help her husband sustain the needs of their family and to prepare for the future of their children. She dreams that someday through the profit her business can generate, she can send her children to school until college.

After having been recognized as a new member of ASHI, Floravie is excited to start her chosen business which is the buying and selling of processed food. She envisions that someday, together with her husband, she will be able to have a space in the market for her business and can buy a tricycle (motorcycle with sidecar used by people as a means of transportation) for hire to be her other business.

loans.use: To start a business buying and selling processed food.

loans.name: Nigora

texts.en:
Nigora E., born in 1987 in Zafarabad region, works with her mother in the local bazaar, trading in fruits (apples, apricots, cherries, etc.) and vegetables (potatoes, onions, and carrots). Because she secures her produce from a collective farm, she has a good assortment and low prices, factors that ensure many repeat customers. Nigora is requesting from Kiva a business development loan of 800 STJ for four months to open her own trade outlet.

MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. In October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest,” together with LLC “Frontiers,” founded the Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand.”

“Arvand,” being the assignee of “MicroInvest,” continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan.

loans.use: To open her own trade outlet.

loans.name: Rachel

texts.en: Rachel T. is from the village of Calaran, Calamba, Misamis Occidental. She is 30 years old, married, and has three school-aged children. Rachel owns and operates a service-based business, primarily providing manicure and pedicure services to local community members. She has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Rachel joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 3,000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide service. This loan will be her first from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to provide service

loans.name: Anonita

texts.en: Anonita S. is from the village of Delapaz, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 47 years old, widowed, and has two adult children. Anonita owns and operates a business raising crops, primarily planting and harvesting rice for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over twenty years and earns approximately 12,525 PHP a month. In 2005, Anonita joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from GDMPC. Anonita is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizer. This loan will be her sixth from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer

loans.name: Lal Mohammad Group

texts.en:
Lal M. is the group leader of Lal M. group. There are two members in this group and each of them would like to receive money for their own business.

Lal M. wants to take a loan for his business of selling car-parts. He wants to buy necessary materials for his business.

G. M. wants to take a loan for his general store business. He wants to make his shop larger.

They are both very happy with this small-loan process in Afghanistan. They thank AFS and all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To  make his shop larger

loans.name: Ural

texts.en: K. Ural was born in 1956 in the Zafarabad region of Tajikistan. He is married and has four children. He has higher education and is a school teacher by professional background but for the last 12 years he has been engaged in the family business. Ural grows vegetables and sells them in the local bazaar. His wife and children help him in the vegetable garden to do the required work. Ural grows potatoes, carrots, cabbages, onions and beets. Ural applies to Kiva with the request of a business support loan of 1,000 STJ for 2 months to open another trade outlet in another local bazaar. It will permit him to increase his business turnover. He has a good reputation as a MicroInvest client and he has not had any delays in previous loan repayments. About MLF MicroInvest MLF MicroInvest is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. A following step of its development sees MLF MicroInvest’s transformation into a micro-loan deposit-taking organization. Therefore, in October 2008, MLF MicroInvest together with LLC Frontiers have founded the limited liability company micro-loan deposit-taking organization “Arvand”. Arvand, being an assignee of MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan.

loans.use: To open another trade outlet

loans.name: Suhrob

texts.ru:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand”
      “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan. 


Сухроб – опытный фармацевт. Собственный аптечный киоск находится в городе Вахдат. Свои кредиты он использует на расширение своего бизнеса. На следующий займ он хочет закупить медикаменты. Он рад сотрудничеству с нашей организацией и благодарит наших партнеров по КИВА.
texts.en:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand” “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan. Suhrob is a skilled pharmacist. He has his own pharmacy shop in the city of Vahdat. He uses his loans for his business. His plans for the next loan include the purchase of medicine. He is happy to be in corporation with this organization and is thankful to the partners at KIVA.

Translated from Russian by Maria Lyuksyutova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of Medicine

loans.name: Mae Joy

texts.en:
Mae Joy T. is from the village of Upper Lamac, Oroquieta City, Misamis Occidental. She is 25 years old. Mae Joy is married and has 3 infant-aged children. To make a living, Mae Joy owns & operates a business venture in the food sector operating a food stall. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling fruits in the local community. Mae Joy has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine Pesos a month for these activities.

In 2009, Mae Joy joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mae Joy is requesting a new loan of 5,000 pesos which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Mae Joy from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand the business

loans.name: Hursandi

texts.ru:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand”
      “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan. 

Хурсанди  – мужчина, который занимается продажей оргтехники. Свои товары он покупает с Оптового рынка «Корвон».  Для увеличения товарооборота он хочет получить повторный кредит. Хурсанди заметил, что с периода первого займа у него увеличился оборотный капитал и прибыль.
texts.en:
Hursandi is a man, who sells office equipment. He buys his merchandise at the Korvon wholesale market. He wants to obtain another loan in order to increase his goods turnover. Hursandi noticed that his working capital and profit increased since the time of his first loan.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increasing goods turnover

loans.name: Rafoat

texts.en:
A. Rafoat lives in Zafarabad region of Tajikistan and is married with 3 children. Rafoat for the last 10 years has engaged in the family livestock and milk processing business. The additional family income she has comes from selling vegetables in the local bazaar.

She first applied to MicroInvest in 2008 and today she is happy to continue co-operation with the MDO “Arvand.” Rafoat enjoys work and works very hard. She is applying to Kiva for the business support loan of 1200 somonis for 6 months for the purchase of special milking equipment. Using modern equipment would make her work safer. Rafoat thanks Kiva for its support and wishes its members all the best.

MLF MicroInvest is one of the leading microfinance organizations rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. MLF MicroInvest sees the next step in its development as a transformation into a micro loan deposit-taking organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF MicroInvest together with Frontiers LLC has founded the micro loan deposit-taking organization Arvand LLC.

Arvand, being an assignee of MLF MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission: to improve the standard of living of the population by creating new opportunities for social and economic development. It does this by providing qualitative financial and technical services to the entrepreneurs of Tajikistan.

loans.use: To buy milking equipment

loans.name: Ni Putu Suantini

texts.en:
Ni Putu Suantini - (DNR.M-0580) is a 39-year-old woman living in the town of Palasari - Melaya. She is married and has 3 school-aged children. To making a living, Ni Putu Suantini owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for sale. Ni Putu Suantini has been engaged in this business for over 6 years and earns approximately 300,000 Indonesian rupiahs (about $29 US) a month from these activities.

In 2008, Ni Putu Suantini joined DINARI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ni Putu Suantini has successfully repaid a previous loan of 1,000,000 rupiahs from DINARI. This previous loan was used to purchase breeding livestock. Ni Putu Suantini is now requesting a new loan of 5,000,000 IDR which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell. The loan will be the second she has taken out from DINARI. Ni Putu Suantini plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to save as a reserve for future emergencies.

About DINARI:

The mission of DINARI is to strive for the preservation of the environment, to empower the poor, and to provide socio-economic development opportunities to small business owners.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Bahasa while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

Ni Putu Suantini - (DNR.M-0580) merupakan 39 tahun wanita. Dia (perempuan) tinggal di kota Palasari - Melaya. Dia (perempuan) menikah dan memiliki 3 anak usia sekolah. Untuk membiayai hidup, Ni Putu Suantini memiliki & menjalankan usaha. Bisnis beroperasi di sektor pertanian. Tujuan utama bisnis tersebut adalah memelihara ternak. Meskipun bukan satu-satunya sarana untuk menghasilkan pendapatan, sumber utama penghasilan bisnis tersebut terutama berasal dari beternak babi untuk dijual. Ni Putu Suantini sudah menjalankan bisnis ini selama lebih dari 6 tahun. Dari kegiatan-kegiatan ini, Ni Putu Suantini menghasilkan sekitar 300,000 IDR sebulan.

Dalam 2008, Ni Putu Suantini bergabung DINARI untuk mendapatkan akses ke layanan keuangan untuk membantu meningkatkan -nya kondisi kehidupan dan kemampuan untuk menjalankan kegiatan bisnis. Ni Putu Suantini meminta pinjaman untuk pertama kalinya dari DINARI. Pinjaman sebelumnya ini digunakan untuk membeli ternak indukan. Dia (perempuan) sekarang meminta pinjaman baru sebesar 5,000,000 IDR. Pinjaman saat ini akan digunakan untuk untuk membeli bibit ternak untuk dibesarkan & dijual di masa mendatang. Pinjaman ini akan menjadi 2nd pinjaman yang diambil oleh peminjam dari DINARI. Ni Putu Suantini berencana untuk menggunakan pendapatan tambahan yang dihasilkan dari bisnis untuk tabungan sebagai cadangan bagi keadaan darurat di masa mendatang.

Tentang DINARI:

Misi DINARI adalah memperjuangkan kelestarian lingkungan, memberdayakan kaum miskin, dan menyediakan kesempatan pembangunan sosial ekonomi bagi pemilik usaha kecil.

*Catatan: Untuk memaksimalkan efisiensi & menurunkan biaya, pinjaman ini ditempelkan menggunakan templat sehingga dapat diterjemahkan otomatis oleh Kiva. . Mengingat bahwa terjemahan manual atas profil memakan biaya besar, Kiva menciptakan templat ini untuk Mitra Lapangan untuk memungkinkan mereka terus menempelkan pinjaman dalam Bahasa sambil memberikan informasi yang bermutu & akurat kepada para pemberi pinjaman Kiva.

loans.use: For baby livestock to raise & sell

loans.name: Rebecca Akoth

texts.en: Rebecca owns a retail shop and salon in Nyalenda, near Kisumu, Kenya. Her shop started as a hair salon. Rebecca employs two other people to wash, relax, and style hair. They also do manicures and pedicures. Many of her customers are her neighbors, but some people come from far away because they know of her work. One of the challenges of her business is that if customers don’t have any income, they stop coming to her salon. Therefore, she decided to diversify her offerings and she began to sell other basic grocery items like sugar and onge out of the same shop. Rebecca is a 30 years old, married, and the mother of three. Her children range from 3-10 years old. Her husband works casually and does not have a permanent job. Besides running this salon, Rebecca is a Community Healthcare Worker; a volunteer in her community. For two days each week she visits sick people in their homes, and counsels them and their caretakers. Rebecca will use this loan to stock her shop; she will buy more of the products that she is running out of. Rebecca hopes that someday she will be able to grow her business into a large salon with many employees and workstations. Her biggest dream is to open a hairdressing school. About K-MET: K-MET, the NGO giving the loan, is unique in that it is not a traditional microfinance institution. Rather, it is a development organization focused on raising health standards in Kenya. Many of the loan recipients from this organization are volunteer community healthcare workers like Rebecca. For more information about K-MET, click here: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=24.

loans.use: To restock popular items in her shop

loans.name: Eraj

texts.en:
T. Eraj is 23 years old and lives in the Zafarabad region of Tajikistan. Eraj is married and has a small child. He works to ensure his family has the things they need and to ensure the good future of his child. Eraj dreams of getting a higher education and wants to try to obtain a university degree. He has a reputation as a hard working man.

Eraj sells children's wear in the local bazaar; he works directly with suppliers from China and sells their goods. He is also engaged in an agricultural business. Eraj and his brother have land where they grow vegetables to sell. He has a good assortment of products for all levels of the population and has repeat customers. Eraj is applying to Kiva for the business development loan of 4,000 somonis for 6 months to enlarge his store's inventory by importing a new assortment of clothing. It would permit him to increase the business's sales and to open a specialized trade outlet in children's wear. Eraj thanks Kiva for supporting small business entrepreneurs.

MLF MicroInvest is one of the leading microfinance organizations rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. MLF MicroInvest sees the next step in its development as a transformation into a micro loan deposit-taking organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF MicroInvest together with Frontiers LLC has founded the micro loan deposit-taking organization Arvand LLC.

Arvand, being an assignee of MLF MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission: to improve the standard of living of the population by creating new opportunities for social and economic development. It does this by providing qualitative financial and technical services to the entrepreneurs of Tajikistan.

loans.use: To expand store inventory

loans.name: Moses Ojowi

texts.en:
Moses is the 34-year-old, married, father of four children, who range in age from 1 year and 8 months, to 12 years old. His children are all in school. His wife works with him in his business.

Moses sells vegetables and fried fish. He purchases tilapia and nile perch from a market in Kisumu, Kenya, and transports the goods back to a place near his home where he sells them. He also sells vegetables like tomatoes and onions.

The challenge of his business are that during the dry season (which is now, July-December), the prices he pays for his vegetables go up and the supply goes down. He will use this loan to buy more fish and vegetables to sell.

Moses says that “when business goes well, I want to become a farmer.” He wants to grow and sell his own food.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables and fish to sell

loans.name: Ni Made Kursini

About DINARI:

The mission of DINARI is to strive for the preservation of the environment, to empower the poor, and to provide socio-economic development opportunities to small business owners.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Bahasa while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

Ni Made Kursini - (DNR.M-0583) merupakan 54 tahun wanita. Dia (perempuan) tinggal di kota Palasari - Melaya. Dia (perempuan) menikah dan memiliki 2 anak usia sekolah. Untuk membiayai hidup, Ni Made Kursini memiliki & menjalankan usaha. Bisnis beroperasi di sektor pertanian. Tujuan utama bisnis tersebut adalah memelihara ternak. Meskipun bukan satu-satunya sarana untuk menghasilkan pendapatan, sumber utama penghasilan bisnis tersebut terutama berasal dari beternak babi untuk dijual. Ni Made Kursini sudah menjalankan bisnis ini selama lebih dari 4 tahun. Dari kegiatan-kegiatan ini, Ni Made Kursini menghasilkan sekitar 350,000 IDR sebulan.

Dalam 2008, Ni Made Kursini bergabung DINARI untuk mendapatkan akses ke layanan keuangan untuk membantu meningkatkan -nya kondisi kehidupan dan kemampuan untuk menjalankan kegiatan bisnis. Ni Made Kursini telah berhasil melunasi pinjaman sebelumnya dari DINARI. Dia (perempuan) sekarang meminta pinjaman baru sebesar 3,000,000 IDR. Pinjaman saat ini akan digunakan untuk untuk membeli bibit ternak untuk dibesarkan & dijual di masa mendatang. Pinjaman ini akan menjadi 1st pinjaman yang diambil oleh peminjam dari DINARI. Ni Made Kursini berencana untuk menggunakan pendapatan tambahan yang dihasilkan dari bisnis untuk mendukung keuangan anggota keluarga langsung peminjam.

Tentang DINARI:

Misi DINARI adalah memperjuangkan kelestarian lingkungan, memberdayakan kaum miskin, dan menyediakan kesempatan pembangunan sosial ekonomi bagi pemilik usaha kecil.

*Catatan: Untuk memaksimalkan efisiensi & menurunkan biaya, pinjaman ini ditempelkan menggunakan templat sehingga dapat diterjemahkan otomatis oleh Kiva. . Mengingat bahwa terjemahan manual atas profil memakan biaya besar, Kiva menciptakan templat ini untuk Mitra Lapangan untuk memungkinkan mereka terus menempelkan pinjaman dalam Bahasa sambil memberikan informasi yang bermutu & akurat kepada para pemberi pinjaman Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase baby livestock to raise & sell

loans.name: Lillian Amondi

texts.en: Lillian is 26 years old and married, and she has five children ranging in age from 1.5 years to 9 years old. Aside from these children, Lillian and her husband are also the caretakers of two orphans, aged 5 and 7 years, from her husband’s side of the family. Lillian sells sukumawiki (a Kenyan vegetable), along with tomatoes, onions, beans, and other items. She buys them at Kibuye market in Kisumu, and she carries the vegetables on her head to the more rural area where she lives. She sells the vegetables from the side of the road near her home and is able to make 5 Kenyan Shillings profit for each tomato that she sells. (approx. seven U.S. cents.) Lillian will use this loan to buy more products to sell. “If you have more, you can get good money,” she said. She wants to buy a larger variety of vegetables, and would like to even buy potatoes and sweet potatoes, to make “chips” (french fries) to sell along with the fresh food. Eventually Lillian hopes to be able to buy building materials so that she can build her own home. Lillian is a community healthcare worker, which means that she volunteers to visit the sick in her community. She explained that she looks after them, and trains their caretakers how to look after them, to wash them, etc. About K-MET: K-MET, the NGO giving the loan, is unique in that it is not a traditional microfinance institution. Rather, it is a development organization focused on raising health standards in Kenya. Many of the loan recipients from this organization are volunteer community healthcare workers. For more information about K-MET, click on the link under “About the Field Partner” on the right-hand side of the webpage.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables to sell

loans.name: Winnie

texts.en:
Winnie is a 29-year-old single mother of two. She is a tailor and a dressmaker – she even made the dress that she is wearing in the photo! She wants to use this loan to buy a new Singer sewing machine which will help expand her business.

Winnie has been a tailor for six years. She went to a training school before starting her own business out of her home. When asked about her challenges, she explains that the road outside of her house is bad; that means that it is difficult for customers to get to her. She also explains that many customers don’t want to pay for high quality work. Sometimes they place an order and when she provides the service, they only pay part of the balance, and then “they disappear” – leaving her to cover the rest of her costs.

Winnie wants her business to grow so that her kids can have a better education. If possible, she wants to buy some land so that some day they can have an actual home.

K-MET, the NGO providing the loan, is not a traditional microfinance institution. Rather, it is a development organization focused on raising health standards in Kenya. For more information about K-MET, click on “About the Field Partner” on the right-hand side of the web page.

loans.use: To buy a sewing machine

loans.name: Omo

texts.en:
Omo B. is from the village of Panduma, Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur. She is 56 years old. Omo is widowed and has 3 adult-aged children. To make a living, Omo owns & operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling "malong" or tube skirts in the local community. Omo has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 3000 Philippine pesos (about $62 US) a month for these activities.

In 2008, Omo joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Omo has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 pesos from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Omo is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offerings. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Omo from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand store inventory

loans.name: Fumilayo

texts.en: Fumilayo sells crates of eggs and noodles at retail to her customers. Fumilayo hopes for the loan amount of 50,000 Nigerian naira to purchase more crates of eggs to sell. Fumilayo is 45 years old and married with three children. She says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase more crates of eggs to sell.

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en:
Eunice, a 37-year-old married mother of three children, ages 7, 13, and 15 years old, is also the primary caretaker of two orphans, (her late sister’s children), aged 16 and 17. An early childhood development schoolteacher, Eunice will use this loan to improve the school by purchasing chairs, tables, charts, and porridge for feedings. Many of the children she works with are vulnerable orphans; five of the 30 children she works with are HIV positive. It is important for her to buy porridge because, she explains, that is sometimes the only meal that these kids get during the day. Not all of the children have someone to pay their school fees, but she takes them at her school anyway.

In the evenings Eunice sells second-hand clothing to make ends meet for her family. She will use part of the loan to buy more clothing.

Eunice explained that she is “living positively:” she is living with HIV and she is living in a positive way. She said it is ok for people to know that about her, and she also wants people to know that people living with HIV/AIDS require good nutrition. If they are taking their ARV medicine properly, they need to be eating well, which is a challenge for many people in Kisumu.

K-MET, the NGO providing Eunice’s loan, is unique in that it is not a traditional microfinance institution. Rather, it is a development organization focused on raising health standards in Kenya. For more information about K-MET, click on “About the Field Partner” on the right-hand side of the webpage.

loans.use: School Furniture and clothes to sell

loans.name: Tuychiboi

texts.ru:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand”
      “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan. 
Туйчибой - молодой мужчина 32 лет. Женат и отец 3-х детей. Образование среднее. Занимается откормом и продажей скота. Жену зовут Бахринисо, ей 30 лет. Она нигде не работает, нянчит своих маленьких детей. А также помогает мужу по хозяйству и откармливает скот. Туйчибой пасет овец на пастбище целый день. Туйчибой кредитуется у нас с 2007 года. За это время он показал себя только с хорошей стороны. Добросовестный и честный клиент. За два года кредитования он увеличил количество своего скота. Туйчибой хочет взять займ для покупки быков.
texts.en:
Tuychiboi is a young man of 32. He is married and the father of three children. He has a secondary school education. Tuychiboi's business is fattening and selling livestock. His wife Bakhrinisso is 30 years old and stays home watching their young children. However, she also helps her husband with the business and feeds the livestock. Tuychiboi is out grazing their sheep on the pasture all day. Tuychiboi has been a conscientious and honest client since he took his first loan out from MLF "MicroInvest" in 2007. The loans he received over the last two years allowed him to increase the size of his herd. Tuychiboi is planning to use this loan to buy more cattle.

Translated from Russian by Susie Armitage, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Fattening and selling livestock

loans.name: Jesebel

texts.en:
Jesebel P. is from the village of Camanga, Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur. She is 36 years old. Jesebel is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Jesebel owns & operates a food stall. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling vegetables in the local community. Jesebel has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 2,000 Philippine pesos (about $41 US) a month for these activities.

In 2009, Jesebel joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jesebel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 pesos from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional vegetables to sell. Jesebel is requesting a new loan of 7,000 pesos which will be used to purchase vegetables to sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Jesebel from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family and to pay the tuition fees of her children.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy vegetables for resale

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose, a 30-year-old married mother of two children, ages 10 and 3, is a self-proclaimed “fish monger” who sells fried fish. She buys the fish daily from the market and transports them by matatu (mini-bus taxi) to Nyamasaria, a more rural area not far out of town.

Rose will use this money to buy more fish, mostly Tillapia from nearby Lake Victoria. She finds that sometimes when she goes to buy fish there are none, so she will use some of the loan money to travel to the shore of the lake where she can buy the fish more directly. Rose hopes to earn enough money from her business to educate her children and to get her “daily bread." Her husband’s income also helps support the family; her husband is a mechanic.

K-MET, the NGO giving providing this loan, is unique in that it is not a traditional microfinance institution. Rather, it is a development organization focused on raising health standards in Kenya. For more information about K-MET, click on “About the Field Partner” on the right-hand side of the webpage.

loans.use: To buy fish to sell

loans.name: Fredrick Obuya

texts.en:
Fredrick is thirty years old and married with three children, ages seven, five and one.  Fredrick does small-scale charcoal dealing. A large truck comes by his house regularly, from which he buys the charcoal in bulk. He then re-sells it to his neighbors when they come by his house.

Fredrick will use this loan to buy more charcoal. Sometimes he does not have enough when customers come to buy it. The loan will ensure that he has a complete supply. Fredrick hopes someday to have a big business so that he can pay his children's school fees. His children are not in school now because he does not have the funds.

Someday, Fredrick hopes to buy a motorbike, and to have a motorbike business to supplement his family’s income that way, as well.

K-MET, the NGO providing Fredrick’s loan, is unique in that it is not a traditional micro-finance institution. Rather, it is a development organization focused on raising health standards in Kenya.  For more information about K-MET, click on “About the Field Partner” on the right-hand side of the web page.

loans.use: To buy charcoal to resell

loans.name: Susan

texts.en: Susan A. is from the village of Tipan, Oroquieta City, Misamis Occidental. She is 42 years old, married, and has six school-aged children. Susan owns and operates a wood lamination business, providing wood lamination services to local community members. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month. In 2009, Susan joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from GDMPC. Susan is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide service. This loan will be her second from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to provide service

loans.name: Anthony

texts.en: Anthony is twenty-three years old and married with two children, ages six and two.  Anthony wants this loan so he can join his older brother in the business of selling shoes. His brother will take him to Nairobi, where he can buy new men’s and women’s shoes. Then he will return to Kisumu, where he can sell the shoes at the main bus station, and at the market on Sundays.  If he is successful with this business, Anthony will expand to other clothing options in addition to shoe sales.

loans.use: To buy a stock of shoes to sell

loans.name: Eva

texts.en: Eva P. is from the village of Manguehan, Lopez Jaena, Misamis Occidental. She is 37 years old, married, and has six school-aged children. Eva owns and operates a business selling charcoal to local community members. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month. In 2008, Eva joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. Eva is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her second from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.name: Azimjon

texts.ru:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand”
      “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan. 
Азимчон мужчина , который на дому построил пекарный цех и производит домашние лепёшки. Узнав от друзей, что можно в кредит осуществить свои планы.Поэтому Азимчон хочет в кредит купить известки и побелить пекарню.На снимке Азимчон в день выдачи.
texts.en:
Azimjon built a small bakery at his home and sells homemade bread called "lepyoshki." He heard from friends about the possibility of taking out a loan to make his plans of repairing the bakery a reality. Azimjon is applying for a loan to purchase lime to whitewash the walls of his bakery. Азимчон мужчина , который на дому построил пекарный цех и производит домашние лепёшки. Узнав от друзей, что можно в кредит осуществить свои планы.Поэтому Азимчон хочет в кредит купить известки и побелить пекарню.На снимке Азимчон в день выдачи.

Translated from Russian by Susie Armitage, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To repair his bakery

loans.name: Ann

texts.en:
Ann is thirty-five years old and a widow with four children, age thirteen to eighteen.  She is a self-professed “fish monger” who sells fried Tilapia in a rural neighborhood area near Kisumu, Kenya.  She purchases the fish from markets in Kisumu, and also from the shores of nearby Lake Victoria.  She will use this loan to buy more fish and to pay for her transportation to and from the lake shore.

Ann hopes to be able to educate her children and to feed them well.  If her business succeeds, it will help her family, she said.

K-MET, the NGO providing Ann’s loan, is unique in that it is not a traditional micro-finance institution. Rather, it is a development organization focused on raising health standards in Kenya.  For more information about K-MET, click on “About the Field Partner” on the right-hand side of the web page.

loans.use: To buy fish to sell

loans.name: Haran

texts.en:
Haran is thirty-one years old and married with one seven-year-old child.  Haran buys new shoes from Kampala, Uganda, and transports them back to Kisumu, Kenya, where he sells them. He will use the loan to buy more shoes.

Haran sells the shoes at the main bus stop in Kisumu. He said that one of his challenges is that his currency loses value; as the foreign exchange rates vary, he sometimes loses money in his business dealings between Uganda and Kenya.

Haran says that his wife helps him with the business sometimes, while their child is in school.

loans.use: To buy shoes to sell

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary sells second-hand bags, shoes and bed sheets. Mary hopes for the loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more second-hand shoes and bed sheets to sell. Mary is 41 years old and married with two children. She says thank you to Kiva lenders and promises to repay her loan promptly.

loans.use: To purchase more second-hand bags and bed sheets to sell

loans.name: Kodjo

texts.fr: Kodjo A. est un homme de 47 ans, marié et père de 4 enfants. il est cultivateur à Avetonou, un village situé à environ 100 kilomètres de Lomé, la capitale du Togo. Cette activité est la principale source de revenus de Kodjo. Il désire avec ce crédit élargir son espace cultivable et payer des engrais et autres intrants pour sa culture.
texts.en:
Kodjo Agbekpono is a 47-year-old man, married, and the father of four. He is a farmer in Avetonou, a village located about 100 km from Lomé, the capital of Togo. This business is Kodjo's main source of revenues. He would like to use this loan to expand his arable land and to buy fertilizers and other inputs for his farming.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To expand his fields and to buy fertilizers and other inputs

loans.name: Sheriffatu

texts.en: Sheriffatu sells frozen foods like fish, beef and chicken. She hopes for the loan amount of N80,000 to purchase more frozen foods to sell. Sheriffatu is 52 years old and has six children. She is married to B.. She says "thank you".

loans.use: To purchase more frozen foods to sell

loans.name: Gulbahor

texts.ru: Гулбахор Туйматова  проживает вместе со своей матерью и сестрой в Зафарабадском районе Согдийской области. Отец Гулбахор недавно ушел из жизни, поэтому ей, как старшей дочери семьи приходится ухаживать за матерью и содержать семью. Гулбахор еще не замужем. У нее есть точка продаж, на рынке «Бадахшан», где она торгует продуктовыми товарами. В ассортимент ее товара входят различного рода сладости, напитки и сухофрукты. В бизнесе ей помогает сестра. Гулбахор хочет получить кредит в размере 4000 сомони, для того чтобы увеличить колличество своего товара и расширить бизнес.
texts.en:
Gulbahor T. lives with her mother and sister in the Zafarabad district of Sogd region. Gulbahor's father recently passed away, so as the oldest daughter, she now cares for her mother and supports the family. Gulbahor is not married. She has a small shop at the Badakhshan market where she sells grocery items, such as sweets, drinks, and dried fruits. Her sister helps her with the business. Gulbahor is requesting a loan of 4000 somoni to supplement her inventory and expand the business.

Translated from Russian by Susie Armitage, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To expand her grocery business
